titleInfo.title: Advanced Bayesian Methods and Applications in Biomedical Data

mods:mods.abstract: Bayesian statistics is a powerful technique for flexibly modeling complex data generation processes. In recent decades, Bayesian methods have gained increased popularity in analyzing biological and spatial data. However, there is much scope for their application in analyzing biomedical data, especially in neuroimaging studies and infectious disease modeling. In Chapter 1, we have focused on Alzheimer's Disease (AD), a leading cause of dementia, and proposed a 'Patient-specific Abnor- mal Region Detection' (PARD) algorithm to identify the heterogeneous abnormal regions in AD patients by solving a Bayesian latent-space variable selection problem. Using Bayesian hierarchical modeling, we have accounted for the heterogeneity as a large-scale variability and incorporated the inherent spatial dependence among the brain cells using Ising and spike-and-slab priors into the latent space. We have conducted an extensive simulation study showing PARD's superiority over competing methods. Finally, we applied PARD to identify subject-specific diseased regions using the MRIs collected from ADNI and constructed sub-group level abnormality maps. In Chapter 2, we have moved our attention to infectious disease modeling, where we have proposed a Bayesian function-on-function regression model to detect abnormal jumps in infection trends. Using three simulation studies, we have shown that the proposed framework can outperform the traditional change-point detection methods by a large margin in terms of detecting significant change points in both linear and non-linear trends while accounting for the effects of functional covariates and ignoring spurious jumps. The proposed framework has been applied to the US COVID-19 trends to identify abnormal jumps that are solely attributable to the infectious disease. In Chapter 3, we applied causal mediation analysis via a Bayesian framework to analyze the causal effects of genetic variations on cognition in AD patients and identify how different brain regions may mediate these effects. Our simulation study validated the effectiveness of the Bayesian framework. Finally, we have implemented the framework for the imaging-genetic and cognitive data collected from ADNI.
